title: 107_hr5198
content: The Act may be cited as the "Premier Certified Lenders Program Improvement Act of 2002". The Premier Certified Lenders Program (PCLP) has successfully helped small businesses expand. Increasing the number of premier certified lenders will provide more resources to small businesses as the Small Business Administration downsizes. However, the PCLP requires lenders to set aside large amounts in loss reserve accounts. Premier certified lenders should maintain loss reserve accounts in amounts reflecting the risk of loss associated with the PCLP loan portfolio. Changing the PCLP to require premier certified lenders to maintain loss reserve accounts reflecting loan risks will protect taxpayers and enhance the program's support for small business development. SEC. 3. ALTERNATIVE LOSS RESERVE FOR CERTAIN PREMIER CERTIFIED LENDERS. SEC. 3. ALTERNATIVE LOSS RESERVE FOR CERTAIN PREMIER CERTIFIED LENDERS. In General, Section 508(c) of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to allow qualified high loss reserve PCLs to elect alternative loss reserve requirements in place of existing ones. Contributions are subject to specific rules outlined in the amendment. A qualified high loss reserve PCL making the election described in subparagraph (A) for a calendar quarter is exempt from making contributions to its loss reserve during that quarter. Companies must make contributions based on the risk of loss before the last day of the quarter. The company must make contributions to its loss reserve before the last day of the quarter to ensure it is at least $25,000 and sufficient to protect the Federal Government from the risk of loss associated with PCLP loans. The term 'qualified high loss reserve PCL' refers to a premier certified lender with a loss reserve of at least $25,000, designated to protect the Government from risks associated with PCLP loans. The company must maintain a loss reserve of at least $25,000 and have a process for analyzing and grading the risk of loss for each PCLP loan. If the company was a qualified high loss reserve PCL in the previous year, additional requirements apply. A third-party auditor must certify the sufficiency of the company's loss reserve to protect the Federal Government from the risk of loss associated with PCLP loans. The term 'PCLP loan' refers to any loan guaranteed under this section.
